posts.name: Rocky
posts.cooked:
Hello intellegent people of FRC community!

Recently I just discovered a new electrical device - CTRE CANivor.

This is what I know about it so far:

I’ve heard some teams use it to create 2 CAN networks for their robot’s drivetrain and superstructure, in case of superstructure CAN bus failure, their drivetrain is still usable and play defense.

I’ve heard it provides higher transfer speed of data. My instincs tell me it allows higher transfer rate of encoder/gyro data, but I didn’t do much research either.

Someome told me that if you use CANivor, you can use pheonix pro license cheaper.

This is what I’m curious:

My team run 1 CAN network from rio to all devices directly and have no problem. A mentor said

“Can bus utilization issues are really only a problem with ctre devices on the bus. Also, if you were to lose a device or the entire bus, the robot code is almost 100% gonna crash. An expensive solution looking for a problem in my opinion”.

It’s indeed $300 dollars, which is 1.5 of a kraken motor. Is it really worth using such a device? I do see lots of team use it, does it give you any benifits?

Legit question . Thanks in advance for any information!

posts.name: Joshua Yang
posts.cooked: I think it gives you faster CAN Bus speed considering that there are two lines instead of one network.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked:
We use a CANivore and have had the RIO CAN bus severed and were still able to drive that much is true.

It is only for specific CTRE devices.    It is good for swerve drive if you are all CTRE as the sensor updates of the Pigeon 2 and CANCoders can all update more frequentlly.

Coupled with phoenix pro it allows you to have timestamps on your messages so you can do proper latency compensation for your encoder messages.

If you are having CAN utilization problems it certainly helps as it has a greater bandwidth.

posts.name: Joshua Yang
posts.cooked: That is very true, you need to have CTRE devices to run it. For example, our robot is a REV bot so we weren’t able to use it. (Hopefully, REV will make something similar in the future.)

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
The CANivore is a higher speed bus than the can on the Rio.  It works differently than the built in can on the Rio as well.  It allows you to have a large number of devices on the bus without creating a CAN utilization problem.

Using the Rio bus, in our experience,  with upwards of 20 items on the bus the CAN devices suffered timeouts regardless of what timing scheme we used.

With the CANivore, we have 27 CTRE devices on the bus and we are under 10% usage, all without any tweaks at all.

It only works with CTRE devices.  However, I’m not sure how solid the reasoning is to have 2 CAN buses.  You’re not actually ‘backing up’ one bus with the other, and if either of them fail you lose critical functionality.  Once it is licensed, it enables a number of “under the hood” features that improve timing.  The real benefit of the latency reduction to most teams is probably not significant.  The licensing is probably secondary to most teams.  The real benefit is the ability to have additional devices on the bus without worrying about overloading it.

posts.name: MrNick
posts.cooked:
I found this blog post from CTRE to be enlightening.

Authored by Cory Often we’ve been asked what the impact higher frequencies, time synchronization, and synchronous API have on critical robot features, such as drivetrain odometry. This devblog will...

If you are all in on CTRE devices for your drivetrain, then there is definitely a benefit to using a CANivore. We are using Phoenix 6 TunerX Swerve and saw a noticeable improvement in our odometry moving from the Rio bus to the CANivore.

posts.name: Simon Gelb
posts.cooked:
Also worth considering that in FIRST ’s recent RFP for a mobile robot controller to replace the roboRIO, one of the requirements was two CAN busses built into the device itself, making the CANivore totally obsolete. This device would be making an FRC debut in 2027, so not counting this year, you are only getting two years of use.

549.14 KB

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 3618 Team Captain / FTC & FLL mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 3618 Team Captain / FTC & FLL mentor

posts.name: porterma64
posts.cooked:
MRC37. USB device port – 1x or other equivalent non-Ethernet way for user to connect and configure device. MRC38. CAN - 2x separate buses, 2.0B 1Mbit. CAN -FD 8Mbps (2.0B compatible) preferred. Up to 4x total buses preferred. Thanks for pointing this out. I’m excited that there may be up to 4 CAN buses though it could be overkill for FIRST . However, be careful what you ask for. Some features that are inherent to the CANIVore, may not make it into this native CAN architecture.  Some other questions though come up but may their own thread are:

Use CANivore as in part of a benchtop Motor/Sensor tester

MCR37. USB port description undefined - why wouldn’t spec 3.1+ or greater?

its also using CAN FD rather than classical CAN , meaning that the data transfer rate is substantially higher. This can be useful for buses that maintain pretty high utilization all the time, and in my experience it can be helpful for drivebases especially.

posts.name: Brian Scharles Jr
posts.cooked:
Rocky_S:

I’ve heard some teams use it to create 2 CAN networks for their robot’s drivetrain and superstructure, in case of superstructure CAN bus failure, their drivetrain is still usable and play defense.

We have our drivetrain on CANivore and superstructure on RIO CAN , but ironically it was our drivetrain CAN that went out twice this weekend (one was a CAN wire getting caught in the swerve gears, the other was a pinched can wire going to our Pigeon, both easy fixes). Which meant we couldn’t drive, but could still tip our pivot up and down and aimlessly wave in the match

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked:
porterma64:

MCR37. USB port description undefined - why wouldn’t spec 3.1+ or greater?

This is tangent to the current topic, but MRC37 is referring to a usb device port “or other equivalent non-Ethernet way for user to connect and configure device”- this would correspond to the usb-b port on the roborio

MRC35 specifies requirements for usb host ports:

MRC35. USB 3.0 host port - 2x required, up to 4x preferred.

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked: It’s not totally obsolete unless the controller actually delivers on CAN FD, which is a preference and not a requirement. It’s also worth noting that FIRST isn’t actually guaranteed to see a proposal that meets every single requirement.

posts.name: Roman A.
posts.cooked: Additionally, the carnivore and its ability to create separate busses will likely still have a place even in that world. As CAN bus utililization among teams only continues to increase and is likely to eventually outpace even the capabilities of a single CAN FD bus (like we saw with the rio and CAN 2.0) over the possibly decade+ lifespan of the 2027 control system. Given the advices in FRC specific control systems products weve seen over the lifespan of the RIO, its not exactly hard to imagine.
